content.body: what did we do to deserve Tom Lord
roc: it seems he's managed to equally annoy all sides of the font discussion
he's veering towards troll status
he's the peter kasting of fonts
I have to say, the whatwg has reached epic bullshit status this week
private feedback has determined there is no suitable codec
I wonder if people realize that is indistinguishable from collusion
I personally would opt for the "screw Apple + Nokia and make Theora the de jure standard, as it's fast becoming de facto"
but I'm not going to push the issue
jcranmer: h.264 is an open standard! didn't you read othermaciej_'s mail?
all of the relevant stakeholders were involved
sayrer: that's why I referred to `de facto' as reasoning
sayrer: which one?
groan
nevermind
I kind of skimmed over them
fair enough
here is my edit: http://blog.mozilla.com/rob-sayre/2009/07/01/offered-without-comment-4/
ah, I found it
I like how people that have gone through media training think they can say anything
it's kind of funny
sayrer: it's not clear to me what problem you have with that statement
it's true that H.264 is an open standard
just like patents are open standards
othermaciej: say it enough and it becomes true
it doesn't mean that you can actually use them
sayrer: the normal definition of "open stanard" doesn't automatically imply royalty-free licensing
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_standard disagrees
"The term "open" is usually restricted to royalty-free  technologies"
(2nd para)
but that was written by hippies, obviously

"The definitions of the term "open standard" used by academics, the European Union and some of its member governments or parliaments such as Denmark, France, and Spain preclude open standards requiring fees for use, as do the New Zealand and the Venezuelan governments."
othermaciej: how about this: proprietary is where you pay
wikipedia seems to disagree with actual standards orgs (as stated in later paragraphs)
funny
wonder why
nearly everyone concurs that "open" == "free" (as in beer)
Ogg Theora on the other hand is not a de jure standard at all, even though it has an open source implementation and is not known to be covered by non-RF patents
but anyway, private feedback settling on MPEG-LA codecs is indistinguishable from collusion
no matter what the intentions are
to me these are all orthogonal factors, and I didn't know that was controversial
it's becoming de facto
as I said before, if Hulu and Youtube both go for Theora in <video>
I mentioned the standards process used for H.264 because getting all the vendors involved is part of why it has an ecosystem around it
clearly not all vendors
H.264 actually had hardware implementations before it saw any significant Web use
just enough to charge others
all right, strike "all" and replace with "many"
"many
er
not that all vendors comrpise "relevant stakeholders"
"many", presumably does not include about 90% of browser market share
yeah, that's true
the Ogg spec, on the other hand, is unilateral, which may be part of why it doesn't have the same level of tools support
please
this is getting pointless
no doubt
later
it's basically a religion war
shrugs
I just wanted to inject some factual information to the discussion
I don't want to get into the religious war part of it
it's not just a religious war, it's a format war
format wars are unpleasant and suck for everyone
well, a standard that 90% of the world doesn't support isn't exactly a useful standard
which is probably why SVG sees so little web usage
2/3 of the web can't use it
er, users
not sure what you're referring to there
standard status is a separate thing from deployment
HTML is SGML, right?
I'll go use <br/ and see how web browsers like it!
HTML 4.01 was SGML in theory but not in practice
HTML 5 is not SGML even in theory
NNTP is UTF-8 in theory, in practice it's whatever-the-server-decides
is not sure how this is relevant to video
it's not what the standard says that matters
it's what the web browsers do
isn't the whole dispute here over what the standard should say?
and if a significant share decides it's untenable to support the standard, the standard will be ignored
the crux of the matter is that the two sides are so extreme in their viewpoint that no consensus can be reached since a significant share would ignore it
that's probably true
we also don't have any input from Microsoft on whether they are willing to implement <video> at all, though they are pretty clearly on record as not being willing to support Ogg
(H.264 will ship as a built-in codec on Windows 7, so I guess they don't have a problem with it as a codec in general)
besides, HTML 5 is essentially, in large part, a codification of de facto web stuff
safari's <video> support is defined as "whatever quicktime supports," no?
if i install XiphQT (Ogg QuickTime components) on my wife's Mac, Safari 4 plays  Ogg video demos
is there any legal reason that every single non-apple stakeholder couldn't bundle XiphQT with their mac installer?
i.e. install mac firefox, get ogg video in safari for free
install mac chrome, get ogg video in safari for free
(yes i work for google, no i haven't discussed this internally. i'm just brainstorming here.)
wouldn't solve the iphone problem, but all modern macs are fast enough to decode ogg video in software anyway
on the desktop, it's just a codec installation problem
mpilgrim: the possibility of installing Firefox leading to other apps breaking is scary
mpilgrim: also, what if someone uninstalls Firefox? do you uninstall the codec? If not, who does the security updates?
mpilgrim: then there's the issue that people who install other browsers probably don't use Safari much
doesn't have to be just browsers
lots of things bundle other things
openoffice and java
xiphqt 0.1.9 was released a few weeks ago
the release before that was in 2007
the other issues are still pretty big issues
but they are not legal ones, to speak to mpilgrim's point
not having access to the system update stream is a problem, for sure
and the end game is probably signed executables on Mac OS X
first they came for your iphone, then your tablet, then your laptop, then your tower
that's not news; even gruber figured that out after the iphone sdk was released
I am agreeing with you, then
yes
usually when that happens, it means it's time for me to reexamine my position
haha
but i think we are in violent agreement on theora and vorbis
well, probably just tactical disagreement
at any rate, I don't think Mozilla would choose to ship/maintain an ogg vorbis implementation if it didn't have to
roc knows better, though
depends what you mean by "have to"
i am... disappointed (but not surprised) that my employer is shipping h.264
If Quicktime and DirectShow supported Ogg Vorbis and Theora, would we just plug into them?
and elated (and surprised) that we are shipping theora
Probably not
it makes total sense if you have a h264 license, kinda
roc, why not?
it makes total sense if you have an H.264 license and don't care whether the Web is royalty-free
well, or you care more about everything working in your minority browser
we have been there, in not so patent-encumbered areas
/don't care/don't care very much/
fair enough
sayrer: http://weblogs.mozillazine.org/roc/archives/2009/06/directshow_and.html
but that
is for any directshow thing
if we sniff for ogg, we could only send ogg
oh, you're suggesting we could use DirectShow but only for Ogg?
well, system ogg from anyone
anyone but us
I don't really see the point
it would just make our lives harder
oh?
we'd be driving the codec from arm's length
that
is true. less control.
we'd have to interact with different versions of the codec
but ogg in firefox would work with ogg in browser foo.
we'd be exposed if the vendor didn't do security updates
that last part is our problem
is unclear how all of these problems don't bother apple
mpilgrim: they control the framework
of third-party codecs?
mpilgrim: and they control almost all the codecs that actual users have installed
they control the things that work on iphones and ipods
and probably apple tvs and god knows what else
mpilgrim: I have been told that there have already been Quicktime changes to make it work better/safer with Web video
there are, I believe, a number of popular QuickTime codec add-ons besides Ogg (I'm not sure Ogg is even the most popular)
i'd guess divx is the most popular
due to existing bundling and massive marketing
they don't work on the ipod though
interoperability problems
the fact that Apple can ship good quality versions of the codecs we care about to all our target platforms is sufficient
we don't consider allowing other codecs to plug in a problem
I wouldn't even rule out a future Safari being able to use DirectShow on Windows
yes, Apple has explicitly stated that control is the issue
so if other people plug in, and don't disrupt that control, it is a non issue
Mozilla seems to have even greater control issues in that you don't even want to let other people plug in (short of forking)
that seems weird to say...
we allow people to plug in and do basically anything
including undermine the business model of our biggest partners
could a firefox extension provide support for other video formats in the <video> element?
I don't know off hand, but I think we should allow that
Quicktime had 10 security fixes in June, for a variety of pretty much unused formats
that's a whole lot of attack surface that I don't really want to be exposed to
in theory, the extension setup should allow it
but there might be details to thwart
mpilgrim: that's not possible right now
fwiw we restrict the set of codecs we support, mainly to remove things that aren't audio/video codecs at all (since QuickTime is overly general) and some obsolete codecs
roc, bummer. how come?
but it's a blacklist, not a whitelist
so third-party codecs are not excluded
sayrer: because the decoder interface is reasonably nice and frequently changing, not an XPCOM pain barrier
oh, and there is no higher level thing to plug into?
short of rewriting the video element, obviously
no
there's the video element
there are decoders, nsOggDecoder and nsWaveDecoder
and there are services that decoders can use, like the media cache
but there is no way to register as a decoder?
no
ok
the decoder list is compiled in
fixing that would be pretty easy
but the interface is very much C++ and not all pure virtual functions
and it changes a lot
we could promise only source compatibility
perhaps the biggest problem is that the symbols you need to use aren't exported from libxul
seems like i've started a constructive conversation
so this is what it feels like...
mpilgrim: no, sayrer's exploring a road that I don't think is that interesting to go down
see, fool's gold
roc, I can see exploding maintainability
roc, but why do you think it is not interesting?
realistically the value of supporting pluggable codecs on the Web is very low
so othermaciej was right; firefox's audio/video support is tightly controlled
since most people won't have them, Web authors can't use them
by virtue of being hardcoded and not extensible
mpilgrim, on one axis, you are right.
i'm not saying it was intentional
it seems more like a side effect
but as you would say, "the end result is the same"
the point of video originally was not to be a plugin based system wasn't it?
fair, but the end result is not quite the same
although roc implied in his blog post that it was an active goal not to support other codecs (no idea if other Mozillians share his views)
once codec, that could be assured to work across all systems
so content providers didn't have to wonde
r if their format would work
I don't think it's oppressive to fail to have extension points
yes, when the full browser is open source
(yes, except for the effing logos, mpilgrim)
if someone's got a great open source codec, and they're willing to do some work, we can integrate it
it may prove to be irrelevant
firefox seems to take share from safari
and Chrome will probably take share from both
there are few codecs that are modern, interesting, used, open, and royalty-free
(for the record, i don't think chrome has any support either for adding video codecs in its upcoming extension system)
one thing that puzzles me is the ambivalence towards mpeg-la's intention to charge
that seems incredibly bad
and it
it's not clear to me that joint client/publishers like apple and google have to face that
what puzzles me is the reluctance of some people I respect to do anything to help avoid a royalty-required format becoming part of the Web platform
I think that they care about other things more
and there is certainly a willingness to believe that the latest winner of a benchmark contest has sealed the deal
i'm pleased to see wikimedia accelerating their plans to integrate theora video into wikipedia
but I wouldn't be surprised to see MS, Opera, or someone else enter at a large advantage. present competition strong though it is.

for what little it's worth, my personal position is that on the whole, royalty-bearing standards and software patents in general are a bad thing for the industry, but I don't have the means to do anything about it in this case
I do think roc's point about the defaults is a good one
the default choice pretty much makes the game
so, you can after extension points, and make them super duper extensible, but it might not matter a whole lot
go after
What works in a default install is probably more important
that's one reason using the system media framework would be different from just having a hypothetical extension point
otoh QuickTime's extensibility could make it easier for Ogg to drive demand
there are two considerations
works in Firefox, works in all browsers on OS Foo
at least, from our perspective :)
some Mozilla derivatives ship many more codecs by default
did google just change the style of the results page a tiny bit?
every time i've done a search in the past like 5 hours i've felt like something was subtly different
I believe Google recently increased the left margin
yeah that's really throwing me off
I'll get used to it eventually :)
holy crap, looks like google search now uses the html5 doctype
i guess this html5 thing really is going to take off
google is now in standards mode!
oh ho ho :-)
That's pretty amazing
maybe standards mode is what screwed up the layout
yeah, maybe
though i'm sure it was intentional
given how much qa that page goes through before shipping
I dunno... I thought the margins were weird
Standards mode makes it suddenly make sense.
they probably ran an experiment where they tested every possible margin from 0px to 20px and used the one that made people the most efficient in searching
hehe
you think i'm kidding...
ezyang: http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/01/business/01marissa.html?pagewanted=3
when I first heard about it I assumed it was based on an experiment to maximize ad revenue
ezyang: (or http://stopdesign.com/archive/2009/03/20/goodbye-google.html - paragraph starting "Yes, it's true")
hoo boy
as demonstrated by public-html, some people don't like reliance on data to make decisions
i do, so i quite like the google atmosphere :-)
opinions about https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=500937#c14 ?
the XMLSerializer thing
wishes XMLSerializer, innerHTML  and XHR didn't have "XML" or "HTML" in their names
Well those Dreamweaver screenshots make it pretty clear that Dreamweaver users are highly likely to write bad table summaries
hsivonen, I suppose what you suggest makes sense for XMLSerializer
annevk5: good :-)
wonders how hard XMLSerializer and DOMParser are to spec now that HTML5 defines all the primitives
was there some kind of solution for running the tokenizer tests in a browser that doesn't expose the interface between the tokenizer and the treebuilder, so you can only observe the tree?
like a JavaScript impl of the tokenizer?
I think Philip` had one
annevk5: no, I mean having a JS harness that feeds html5lib tokenizer test to the browser-native parser and makes conclusions from the tree output rather than raw token output
cool. a word on codecs form Opera.
oh I see, hmm
so in that case run in Gecko it would show if the Java to C++ translator introduced bugs into the tokenizer
huh? Mozilla supports MJPEG in ? demo?
hsivonen: I think he's referring to MIME multipart JPEGs
"word on codecs from Opera"?
roc: I assume hsivonen meant http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/whatwg-whatwg.org/2009-July/020696.html
roc: ok. no real MJPEG then.
yes, I meant http://lists.whatwg.org/pipermail/whatwg-whatwg.org/2009-July/020696.html
ah
i guess we should have announced that somewhere more visibly
visible, even
does the Opera 10 beta do <video>?
othermaciej: no
<video> will be post Opera 10
How do I find out about the security update policies for given packages in Ubuntu "universe"?
wonders what nobinonly in Ubuntu package names means
no binary-only? but what does that signify?
sees that Hixie's email to the ""<" inside tags" thread is rendered as "- Show quoted text -   - Show quoted text -"
Philip`, in which mail client is it rendered like that?
Lachy: Gmail
(which collapses parts that are repetitions of previous parts of the thread)
woohoo! Opera has added OpenType support since the first 10 Alpha. more interop!
People who want interop in practice will have to provide EOT to IE users, and IE only supports fonts with TrueType outlines :-(
Philip`: only people who care about feature parity in IE
i.e. most people in the real world
whew. finally caught up with my other-than-public-html W3C email
mostly by not reading all the Origin and font threads
Philip`: I think we need some scare quotes and different points of view around "real world" :-)

hsivonen: But I have data, so I necessarily win the argument conclusively - out of three people who've contacted me about my font optimizer tool, one wanted it for PDFs and the other two wanted to generate EOTs :-)
Philip`: bah. data. I claim expertise!
seriously, though, I think we need to get authors create sites that use the new Web platform features even when IE doesn't support them
and fonts seems to be particularly additive rather than a feature that makes content unbrowsable if not supported
hsivonen: hard to sell something to a client that looks 'right' in everything but IE
beowulf: this has to start with sites that aren't made for clients
nods
sites for client is kind of old-fashioned anyway
clients*
whoa: http://example.com/iestandards.xml
IE8 is also introducing magic URLs now? http://blogs.msdn.com/ie/archive/2009/07/01/ie-compatibility-list-pruning.aspx
sighs
looks forward to more fun hours updating an already cluttered flowchart
you know it makes sense
also how it's not per origin but per registered domain
it's insane
they must be on some pretty bad enterprise crack
what could be better than making spurious HEAD requests on every web site you visit?
also funny that they called the header x-ua-compatible and this file is clearly vendor specific
was this behavior always there or does this come in an autoupdate or something?
I think the file is actually IEStandards.xml, not iestandards.xml
which is kind of an important distinction for anyone not using IIS
who wouldn't use IIS in the real world?
hsivonen: Looks like it was there in the original release
http://blogs.msdn.com/askie/archive/2009/03/23/understanding-compatibility-modes-in-internet-explorer-8.aspx
IESettings.xml?
Philip`: ok. thanks
comments on the blog
Oops, they do mentioned "IEStandards.xml" already, it's just the example.com that's wrong
*mention
wow. a rare Jeremy Keith posting to whatwg
short, but to the point
sayrer, re your latest email, what do you mean by "the HTML5 specification"?
it's a noun, isn't it?
mkay, assuming you mean the one Hixie edits, I wonder how you're going to do it :)
oh, I'll make a copy and change it from there
no edit wars
But edit wars add drama to life!
sayrer, ah ok, makes sense
gsnedders: I have accepted your feedback. I will reply with 4 months
within
sayrer: Only four? Dude, you need to learn how to edit specs! :)
gsnedders: it says so right on there on my blog
oh wait, that's elementary web design
I get confused easily
think gsnedders life just exstended with 4month?
(edit wars works for me, but I believe only Hixie has write access to the source file so any changes would be overwritten each time the spec is generated)
Actually, I was looking at the source
and there are these comments saying "YOU MUST TALK TO IAN BEFORE CHANGING THIS TEXT"
I wonder who those are directed to
I decided they don't apply to me
That was because of changes made before publication to /TR/, I believe
W3C pubteam
ah I see
I won't be taking feedback via the whatwg lists, so I have to change some parts
i wouldn't expect it to apply to forks anyway
that wouldn't make sense
but are you sure you're looking at the source?
it might be a header file that had that
I don't think it would make sense, either
but... Please leave your sense of logic at the door, thanks!
yadayada
also, I need to update the spec to disallow private feedback on certain issues
basically anything controversial
I thought about trying to disallow it completely, but it seems like I would have to recuse myself from hallway conversations
not a credible way of going about things :)
"No, sorry, I can't accept your comment. Good bye."
on video codecs, that's exactly what I'll say
well, maybe "send your comment to the list" would be better, and a touch more polite
so you're saying you will no longer have hallway or lunch conversations on <video>?
sounds pretty tough
on codecs
there are plenty of other parts
In fact, I won't even discuss codecs here
only on the list
that is starting now or so?
doesn't really matter I suppose; anyway, I'm curious what your draft will look like
Someone should give me CVS access so I can make a version of the spec where all the letters are upside down
Philip`: that would be awesome!
or you could make all 'i's that Turkish cahracter that looks like 'i' but without the dot
takkaria: Maybe I should replace them all with http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3C!DOCTYPE%20html%3E%0D%0A%26%23x131%3B%3Cblink%3E%26%23x307%3B%3C%2Fblink%3E
except sadly that appears to be buggy in pretty much all browsers :-(
Firefox and IE on Windows ignore the styling of the dot entirely
Firefox on Linux doesn't even draw the dot

sayrer, re http://blog.mozilla.com/rob-sayre/2009/07/02/secrets/ - why are you surprised that Hixie accepts feedback that gets sent to him privately? That's certainly not the first time he's mentioned that and it would be silly for him to reject it
I am not surprised
no comment on the silliness
ok, then I'm not sure I get the point of what you're trying to say about it
Lachy: I can live with that
wonders if it worth pointing out that we may be unable to get consensus on not specifying codecs, decides it is not
jgraham, so we're damned if we do and damned if we don't? Cool!
Lachy: damn you.
Why do people like Flash and <video> more than they like <embed>/<object> methods of embedding videos?
I think it's because they promise to "just work"
well, ignoring the fact that Flash uses object/embed, using object/embed for regular video files historically depends on 3rd party codecs that may not be present for all users
What should .min and .max return on an HTMLInputElement which doesn't allow min/max?
whereas Flash already has sufficient market penetration for that problem to be ignorable
gsnedders, what does the spec say?
Lachy: I can't find the spec saying anything.
(wrt to this)
gsnedders: undefined, no?
Because you are doing a property lookup of a non-existent property
jgraham: But the spec says min/max return a DOMString, so surely that's wrong?
the spec says they should reflect the content attributes
Oh you mean in the case where min/max are supported but not relevant to that particular type of input
Yes
so my guess is that even though they don't apply to certain controls, should still return whatever values were specified (if any) or the default value if not
gsnedders: Empty string then
(or the values that were supplied)
From my reading of the spec they should return an empty string or what was given.
There is no default value.
The empty string is the deafult value
so we all agree
No need for anyone to get CVS access and modify the draft or anything
aw, you sound a little snarky :(
hope everything is ok :)
This is IRC, you're not allowed to be snarky in here!
won't dare get in the way of any Boojumic snarkiness, however
"The value DOM attribute is in mode filename."  does that mean it only ever returns one?
What does "in mode" mean?
(quick, while jgraham's away from his computer!)
Oh, wait.
If I follow the xref

Some days ago I started reading about html5 and the features it consists. The offline capabilities are very interesting, especially the client side SQLite database. I want to start learning html5, and for this I need to develope my own applications.
But for this I need a html5 capable browser. I am working on a ubuntu 9.04 machine. Which browser should/can I use to start developing web apps which use some html5 features?
or how does the development environment looks like which you guys use to develope html5 enriched web apps?
http://www.w3.org/News/2009#item119
jgraham: You wouldn't happen to know how much posting something to GB costs?
hober: woah
gsnedders: 12SEK or so I think
mr_daniel: I think webkit based browsers are the most likley to have SQL support at the moment
Although chrome doesn't afaik and I'm not sure about other webkit-based linux browsers
Otherwise Opera, Firefox, Webkit based browsers, and, to a lesser extent, IE8, all implement some HTML5 features
hober: I wonder how the "more resources" will be depolyed to help us reach LC/CR
jgraham: Right, thanks
needs a screwdriver
where do you post things here?  I've not seen any letterboxes
takkaria: They are yellow and could be mistaken for bins
hm, armed with that knowledge, I will pay more attention
ok, I guess it takes at least some months until html5 has broder support
takkaria: I have seen places.
Hmm, my MBP appears to have decided that I no longer deserve any graphical output
Philip`: That's what happens when you insinuate MikeSmith is a lemming
That's correlation, not causation
Philip`: Prove it
jgraham: No
I'll just assert that it is true
Hmm. Stupid ide of the day: use @title on <tr> containing column headers to help build an autosummary of the table. Dunno how you would do row headers though
*idea
new rule: data is forbidden
jgraham: <col>?
takkaria: Doesn't work in existing browsers though
Plus <col> is silly
yeah, I thought much the same thing
evn sillier I mean
Actually, re there any good use cases for <col>?
Why do we still have it?
For styling columns?
Dashiva: Does that actually work?
no
You could use tr > td:nth-of-type or something
(although that wouldn't allow for hte possibility of mixed td/th in rows)
jgraham: It also fails with colspan
True
jgraham: It works in some browsers, with some styles
Styling <col>, that is
CSS could grow a column selector I guess
(but colspan seems hard in general. What happens if I style the third column but have a cell that spans from the first to the fifth column?)
(I guess it shouldn't be styled)
Hixie got there a while ago: http://ln.hixie.ch/?count=1&start=1070385285
IE supports it and no-one else does apparently
Oh noes, ianh, you made a parser change :-o
stabs Hixie
Looks like a fairly trivial change tho
It's just making another char throw a parse error
Good Shelley is around, the list would be much too quiet otherwise
yay for impls that don't report parse errors
wonders how hard it'd be to get the html5lib tree builder tests running in browsers
gsnedders: zcorpan did it already
jgraham: Oh.
gsnedders: Not sure where though
had never heard about it before
ezyang: don't blame me, blame zcorpan! :-P
Hehe
Hixie: But he's on holiday, so it's harder to blame him :P
someone should let plh and ij know about the author-only mode of the html5 spec
Hixie: Hixie?
see the last q of the rip-xhtml2 faq
linky?
http://www.w3.org/2009/06/xhtml-faq.html
The link was broken when I last looked at the news so I hadn't read that yet :P
http://www.w3.org/2009/06/xhtml-faq.html
Sigh. I threw in my lot with the XHTML Modularizatoin
*Modularization
Hmm, Steven Pemberton just gave a talk about XHTML2 on Tuesday :/
That's... pretty big news
Shouldn't this say "any markup language using XML namespaces"? -- "RDFa is a specification for attributes to express structured data in any markup language."
man, @w3c has now twice tweeted that the xhtml2 wg is being expired
CURIEs will be published as a note, not a recommendation?  that's interesting
i wonder why they're so eager to announce this
I wonder how they came up with the questions in http://www.w3.org/2009/06/xhtml-faq.html
some of them seem quite silly
takkaria: You aren't, under the W3C process, allowed to just stop working ona doc. You need to either publish a REC or a NOTE
like "Does W3C plan for the XML serialization of HTML to remain compatible with XML?"
gsnedders: "n[o]t[...] allowed" - what could they do if you stop anyway?
Philip`: Move it to another WG.
the faq does rather gloss over the fact that html5 is a w3c-whatwg joint venture
Is it then?
I thought the W3C only did the marketing part :)
nah we get lots of feedback from the public-html list
http://www.zeldman.com/2009/07/02/xhtml-wtf/
Yeah, I still have to thank you all for giving me something to do in the train
"I plan to use XHTML 5 served as text/html, just to tork off the purists, just like I do now with XHTML 1.0."
it's actually impossible to do that
xhtml5 served as text/html5 is just html5
(the definition of "html5" vs "xhtml5" is the mime type used)
Wikipedia is being really slow for me
